results.title: The Family Law
results.brief_description: Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a unique perspective on what it means to be Australian today.

constellations_primary.name: The Family Law
constellations_primary.description: An exploration of Asian representation on screens around the world that delves into TV, cinema, documentaries and Disney princesses.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

constellations_other.name: Tony Ayres
constellations_other.description: Charts the acclaimed career of Tony Ayres through his work in film and TV.

results.description:
Fourteen-year-old Benjamin Law is desperate to win his school’s talent show. Not only must he chart a course to high-school stardom, but he also needs to navigate all the issues of Australian adolescence: embarrassing parents, bickering siblings, school bullies, best friends and his own sexuality.

Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book of the same name, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a uniquely Asian Australian perspective on what it means to be Australian today.

“I really do think that when you’re a storyteller, and that’s what the media and the arts are, you do have a responsibility to tell the stories and a full range and diversity of what those stories actually are out there.” - Benjamin Law

Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book of the same name, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a uniquely Asian Australian perspective on what it means to be Australian today.

“I really do think that when you’re a storyteller, and that’s what the media and the arts are, you do have a responsibility to tell the stories and a full range and diversity of what those stories actually are out there.” - Benjamin Law

results.title: The Family album
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Developing image”.
Highlights the most frequent subject of photographers past and present, the family portrait. Provides a history of family portraiture, including daguerreotypes and wet-plate photography, as well as the development of Kodak roll-film cameras. Includes interviews with leading contemporary photographers who specialise in family portraiture.

results.title: The Family
results.creator_credit: Herbert Kerkow and United States. Army
results.brief_description: Family life as lived by a father, mother, two children and a grandmother is depicted. They are not in affluent circumstances and conflicts arise because the father wants to repair the house, mother wants a sewing machine, and the daughter a ball dress. They get together and talk out their problems; by so doing they strengthen the bonds of family life and create a sense of security among themselves.

results.title: The Falls
results.brief_description: A film which obsessively seeks to construct a self-sufficient world complete with a multiplicity of exotic languages and ornithological references. Ninety-two improbable surnames all with the prefix FALL have been randomly picked out as a block from the nineteen million names in the Standard directory of the Violent Unknown Event (VUE). Part 1 comprises 45 case histories (from FALLA to FALLBUTUS) presented through commentary, interview or enactment. Part 2 comprises 47 case histories (from FALLCAS to FALLWASTE) presented through commentary, interview or enactment. Director, writer, editor, Peter Greenaway ; music, Michael Nyman ; photography, Mike Coles, John Rosenberg.

results.title: The Fallout atom
results.creator_credit: Harold Mayer, Michael Sklar and Columbia Broadcasting System
results.brief_description: An examination of the scientific facts of human radiation filmed at the Argonne National Laboratory of the AEC in Lemont, Ill. Dr John E. Rose attempts to find out how much radioactive material the human body possesses naturally, how much we have been exposed to as a result of nuclear bomb tests, and the effects of radiation on health and life. Shows the tests of two groups of human guinea pigs; one group - radium dial painters who literally ate radium 30 years ago, and another group whose everyday drinking water has a higher-than-average percentage of radium.

results.title: The Fallen idol. The Winslow boy
results.creator_credit: Graham Greene, Carol Reed, Terence Rattigan, Anthony Asquith, Anatole de Grunwald and London Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Based on a true incident, ‘The Winslow Boy’ (produced by Anatole de Grunwald, directed by Anthony Asquith) tells the simple story of a father’s impassioned fight to clear the name of his son - a young naval cadet expelled from college after being found guilty of theft. Arthur Winslow is certain of his son’s innocence, and yet is impeded in his task to retain the boy’s honour, that is until a famous KC and political leader, Sir Robert Morton, agree to help their cause. Cast includes Robert Donat, Cedric Hardwicke and Margaret Leighton.
Based on a short story by Graham Greene, ‘The Fallen idol’ (produced and directed by Carol Reed) is a sensitive study of the way in which a young boy interprets the strange and seemingly illogical behaviour of the adults who surround him. He witnesses the adulterous relationship that develops between the butler Baines, whom he worships, and a typist at the foreign embassy in London where his father works. He also sees Baines’ wife fall to her death while spying on the couple and the boy’s interpretation of events places Baines in a perilous situation. Cast includes Michele Morgan, Ralph Richardson, Sonia Dresdel and Jack Hawkins.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Graham Greene, Carol Reed, Terence Rattigan, Anthony Asquith, Anatole de Grunwald and London Film Productions

results.title: The Fallen idol [study extract]
results.brief_description: The excerpt covers the following: Baines, Julie and Felipe and a day of stolen happiness with a riotous game of hide and seek in the empty Embassy, not knowing that Mrs Baines is spying on them. Felipe is awakened later by Mrs Baines who tries to involve him in her plot against her husband. The terrified boy witnesses a violent struggling quarrel between husband and wife, and believes that Baines has killed his wife. He rushes into the night in his pyjamas but is apprehended and taken in charge by a friendly policeman. The extract is chosen to illustrate Reed’s style, his ability to handle actors, (especially the child), the use of a large number of shots and quick cutting back and forth, imaginative lighting and the creation of suspense.

results.title: The Fallen idol
results.creator_credit: Carol Reed, David O. Selznick and London Film Productions
results.brief_description: An ambassador’s small son nearly incriminates his friend the butler in the accidental death of his shrewish wife. A near-perfect piece of small-scale cinema, built up from clever nuances of acting and cinematic technique. Written by Graham Greene. Stars Ralph Richardson. Rated: PG

results.title: The Fall of the World Trade Center [Widescreen]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
September 11, 2001 will be remembered for many years to come and will be written into the history books as one of the world’s major life-changing events, horrific and unbelievable, and one which had an immediate impact on peoples of all religions and races across the globe. Terrorism has been around for centuries but the attack on the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center in New York took terrorism on to another level - 2,800 people died out of an estimated 14,000 people who were in the towers when two jet planes, hijacked by terrorists, hit. The irony of the collapse of the towers is that they were the first skyscrapers explicitly designed to withstand being hit by a jet plane. Built in 1966, the World Trade Center was hailed as innovative, both in concept and design, and on completion the Twin Towers became the world’s tallest buildings. This program presents an indepth look at the history of the Twin Towers, from their inception through to Ground Zero in an attempt to explain the reasons why they did collapse and why so many people died. Features testimonies from eye witnesses, experts and official investigators including Leslie Robertson, designer and head structural engineer of the World Trade Center Project in 1966. Also includes graphic footage of the “attack” and the “collapse” of both towers, computer animated images of the structural design and actual archival footage of the towers being constructed. This is a fascinating and well documented program. However, the implications resulting from the conclusions reached are disturbing as many modern skyscrapers built since the Twin Towers are based on the same structural concepts and design. The question is asked: “Can anything be done to make modern lightweight skyscrapers more robust in the aftermath of September 11?”. Narrated by Jack Fortune. For more information see: http://www.bbc.co.uk/science/horizon/2001/worldtradecenter.shtml

results.title: The Fall of the Roman Empire
results.creator_credit: Anthony Mann, Samuel Bronston and Samuel Bronston Productions
results.brief_description: In second century Rome Emperor Marcus Aurelius plans to make the heir to the throne his adopted son Livius, rather than his biological son Commodus. Indignant with rage, Commodus has his father murdered and succeeds him, declaring himself a God. When Commodus discovers that his sister, Lucilla has a stronger claim to the throne than he, Commodus sentences her to burn at the stake. This sword-and-sandal epic harked back to successful 1950s biblical dramas with its lavish sets, scores of extras, remarkable action sequences and a chariot race. The exorbitant cost of the film (and poor audience reception) financially ruined producer Samuel Bronston. It has been speculated that audiences were tiring of such lavish productions and timing may have also hurt the film’s box-office - it was released the same year as the opulent Burton/Taylor epic “Cleopatra”. Cast includes Sophia Loren, Christopher Plummer, Alec Guinness, Omar Sharif and James Mason.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Anthony Mann, Samuel Bronston and Samuel Bronston Productions
